article: I've often puzzled over something that happened to me one winter when I was eight. Over the years I had been wondering if my _ was nothing more than a kid's imagination. There was a _ near our house. In winter it was the greatest _ place in the world. One _ all I wanted to do was go skating. I had been waiting for weeks _ the water was frozen solid. Mom had one rule: "Never ice-skate alone." But I couldn't _ any longer that afternoon. So I _ my skates under my coat and ran to the pond. Several people were skating near the shore, and some kids were playing hockey.I was not really _ . The hockey game had attracted _ audience, so I skated in the other direction until their cheering _ But another noise came soon. The ice was cracking beneath me. Freezing water _ my body, and I sank like a rock. My feet _ e bottom. Just when I thought I wouldn't last another _ , I felt a tap on my shoulder. "Don't worry," someone said. I swung my _ around. I couldn't see anybody. But I heard the voice again,"Push your feet into the bottom and you'll shoot straight up to the surface." I did as I was told and _ . I crawled to the shore and lay down, _ .The next thing I knew was people were _ around me, covering me with coats. When I awoke, I was home in my own bed. Mom sat next to me, _ my hand. "I saw nobody there. It must be an angel that came to my _ ." I said. Mom smiled, "I just thank God you're safe." For a long time I thought I would come up with a more realistic explanation if I just thought hard, but I never did.
